title: Agaricus macrosporus
text:
Agaricus macrosporus is a rare, <a href="edible%20mushroom">edible mushroom</a> found from June at wood fringes and in meadows.
Description.
The white <a href="Pileus%20%28mycology%29">cap</a> is hemispherical and white when young, but later flattens out up to 25 cm in diameter and becomes yellowish or tan. Its <a href="Trama%20%28mycology%29">flesh</a> is very thick. The <a href="Gill%20%28mycology%29">gills</a> are pinkish grey when young, and become brown with age. The <a href="spore">spore</a>s measure 12 by 6 <a href="Micrometre">μm</a> and are purplish-brown and almond-shaped. The <a href="Stipe%20%28mycology%29">stem</a> is strong and thick, with a broad ring. It may measure 8 to 12 cm in height and up to 3 cm in diameter.
The flesh is white with a mild taste and a smell of aniseed, turning slowly orange when cut.
Similar species.
There is a danger of confusing this mushroom with the deadly poisonous bulbous agaric "<a href="Amanita%20phalloides">Amanita phalloides</a>" and "<a href="Amanita%20pantherina">Amanita pantherina</a>". "<a href="Agaricus%20excellens">Agaricus excellens</a>" is different by its taller and slimmer stipe which is striped lengthwise. "<a href="Agaricus%20augustus">Agaricus augustus</a>" does not have the pure white cap in young specimens.
